name: Taylor
comment info: How might the release of albums, singles, or music videos affect each artist's popularity? Releasing a music video within the time frame observed would elevate an artist's popularity levels all over. Even those who aren't fans might watch a new music video just to be up-to-date with the current pop culture. How could the race of artists and the demographic of an area relate? Rihanna and Drake are popular is metropolitan areas, cities. Rihanna is especially popular in the south and along the east coast. Taylor Swift is popular in the wheat belt and mountainous west. It would be interesting to know the exact correlation between the popularity and the racial demographics.

name: Wyatt
comment info:
http://www.censusscope.org/us/map_nhblack.html

I noticed the areas where Black people are the majority in populations tend to like Black artists drastically over White artists. I attached a map above, check for yourselves.

name: Noah Hammond
comment info: only listen to like two of them or so.

name: Ava
comment info: I notice that each artist is popular in different regions of the US. I wonder what time of releases of albums and songs have effect on these graphs and what different regions of the US and different lifestyles have affect on these results.

name: Erik Sheckler
comment info: Interesting to see that Drake is more popular in Cali than Luke Bryant is

name: LIFE SCHOOL
comment info: These graphs show the level of popularity for charted Billboard artists/singers in all 50 states in the U.S. The graphs also show that people in all different areas around the United States are interested in very different genres of music. I also noticed that based on the key below each of the graphs, we can easily see the areas in which each artist is most-least popular. What’s interesting is, the physical placement of where these artists seem to be popular/unpopular are solely based on the way of living in these different States. I was surprised to see that Rihanna was actually more popular in the South than the North… It’s really evident that there are major differences across our country when looking through music.

name: Lisette Rodriguez
comment info: Why now? Why are these graphs brought out into perspective about a year later when the time frame of these views on YouTube was between January 2016 to April 2017. Also, referring to the previous comments, the artists do appeal to different regions of the United States based on the genre of music. At the same time, artists like Drake and Rihanna have similar genres in music because they both sing Hip Hop and R&B. What I find interesting is that although Drake and Rihanna use the same genre in music, they both receive the most popularity in opposite coasts of the United States.

name: Nataly Madrigal
comment info: Based on the graphs, I notice that the artists shown are the artists that are the most popular in their genre, and each genre differs popularity in differnt regions. Rihanna being a mostly R&B singer has higher popularity in the southeast. Drake being an artist in the hip hop industry has the highest popularity in the in the southwest, Taylor Swift being mainly pop has the highest popularity in the west and Midwest, and Luke Bryan being a country singer is the most popular in the mid-Atlantic right between north and south east. These regions are completely different indicating that one genre is more biased in a specific region.

name: Deija Robins
comment info: I notice that in certain areas of the United States some are darker than others, which are lighter. Taylor Swift and Luke Bryan are considered to be country artists, in which their darker areas are in the rural or country parts of the United States. Rihanna and Drake are not as popular as someone would think in the United States. Drake is more popular in the West than in the East, and for Rihanna, it is the exact opposite.  The Billboard Top 100 are bias because it shows that Rihanna is the number 2 person who is the most watched on Youtube, but the graph shows that she has less people across America not listening to her music. Artists like Taylor Swift and Luke Bryan have more of the United States covered than Rihanna or Drake. It can be speculated that these may have paid of Billboard to help them sell more of their records.

name: Dennise Sy
comment info: I noticed that Drake, Rihanna, Luke Bryan, and Taylor Swift differ in popularity between certain parts of the United States, and that lighter colors indicate that the artist is not very popular in the area, while darker colors indicate that the artist is extremely popular. I wonder why the graph is limited only to the United States instead of the whole world. This could mislead people when they are aware that one artist is more popular than the others, only to be proven otherwise by the graph. The popularity of artists are not represented accurately because the information from Billboard Top 100 does not specifically assert that it is limited only to the U.S.

name: Kashmaila Ali
comment info:
I wonder how the makers of the graph determined which singers were more popular because there are variables that need to be taken in account for instance, how populated a state is.  I also wonder how they differentiated between different users who played the video more than once.
These details imply that we as a society have certain social norms. For instance, we expect Luke Bryan to be listened more by the Southern States, but he is not. The same goes for Rihanna because I expected her to be extremely popular in California due to the type of music she puts out. This shows that we automatically associate certain music to certain areas based on stereotypes.
Rihanna is the most popular artist on the graph; however, she is less popular throughout the states. This is due to the fact that Rihanna is more popular in densely populated states. While Taylor Swift is more popular by state size, the states she is popular in are not highly populated; whereas the East Coast is. The claim that can be made is the Rihanna is number 2 because she is popular in more densely populated states.

name: Milen Aklilu
comment info: I notice that the different genres of music these four artists occupy are popular in different sections of the country and I wonder why certain artists don’t appeal to certain demographics in this country.

name: Kendrick Rodriguez
comment info: I am curious where other artist would be heard, such as Ed Sheeran, Post Malone, XXXTentacion. I am also curious where Lil Xan, Lil Pump, and 6ix9ine are being heard, considering that their music is so "Influential".

name: Angelica Leon
comment info:
I notice that there are many comparisons being made such as female and male, black and white, rap and country,  west coast and east coast, north and south, and top artist to least popular artist. I also notice through out these graphs that California seems to be very diverse with these different artists.
I wonder why Alaska and Hawaii do not have much bias towards any of these artists.

name: Xander Lambright
comment info: I wonder how the shades of purple are decided. The scale says it's from "less popular" to "more popular", but what are the intervals for those. Such as, is every 100000 searches another notch on the scale?

name: Juan Galvez
comment info: I think that the reason as to why Taylor Swift looks so popular but is still in a lower rank than Drake, even though he seems to cover less of the U.S. is population. Drake's fan base is mostly the West Coast and as a California native I can confirm that the West Coast states have a much bigger population than all of the Midwest put together. Yes, the Midwest looks like a much bigger part of the U.S., but it doesn't necessarily mean it has more people living in it.

replies.name: T
replies.comment info:
@Juan Galvez
I agree, population in areas plays a key role in an artist's stream count and their national popularity. I would also wonder since the Midwest is pretty homogenous, how the diversity of more populated areas affects who is viewed more.

name: Juliana Hernandez
comment info: What I notice in the graph provided is while Rihanna seems to be more popular on the East Coast, Drake is most popular on the West Coast. As for Taylor Swift she is most listened to on the West side towards California and Luke Bryan shows some popularity in the Northern States.I wonder how Taylor Swift is considered the most popular of the four yet Rihanna is ranked #2 on the Billboard charts and Taylor is ranked 18.  Drake also seems to have that issue being ranked 13 and still falling short on the popularity scale to Taylor Swift.What might be occurring on the graph is African American artist being compared to Caucasian artists. Given that Rihanna and Drake are similar in genre of music, they are being compared to Taylor Swift who in 2012 was labeled a country singer at the time and Luke Bryan who is still a present country singer. So genres of music are also being compared and where they are most popular.

name: Evan Dunn
comment info: I am curious on why Rihanna is #2 and she isn’t as popular in those certain states and Luke Bryan is #42 and he is more popular throughout the country. I am also very curious on why certain artists are favored in opposite coasts. I notice that the more purple the music artists are in the US, they are more popular. I notice that each artists has a different audience based on where they are most popular.

name: Carlos Lopez
comment info: I notice that artists that are in genres such as r&b and rap are more popular in more densly packed states such where as the east coast. Meanwhile, artists who are in the country genre tend to be more popular in the western states where the population is not as dense

name: Andrea H
comment info: I have noticed that of course we expect artist such as Rihanna and Drake to be the most popular all around, but these graphs are the data of the artist music, and not the popularity of the artist themselves. We do expect different popularity for each artist that what is portrayed on the graph.

name: Raymond Togagae
comment info: Looking at this graph, I am concerned with the fact that for the African-american  music artists who are Drake and Rihanna, most of the southern states take a liking to their music, however, they aren't as popular in most of the Northern states. The same goes for the white music artists who are Taylor Swift and Lucas  Bryan, most of the Northern states are more oriented towards their type of music genre. This observation makes me think that this graph not only discloses the popularity of several celebrities nationwide, but it also represents the racial conflict that still resides within the United States.

name: Joshua
comment info: The stereotypes that come with certain genres of music are not always true. For example, Luke Bryan, who is meant to represent country music, does not have the kind of popularity in Southern States like Texas. Furthermore, you wouldn’t expect Drake to be so popular in Texas. This proves that the stereotypes we construct n our brain are not necessarily true.

name: Karen C
comment info: I notice that the artists are more popular in the areas that they are from, yet Taylor Swift has more popularity in various regions of the United States.

name: Tiffany Waithaka
comment info: I noticed that the charts are based on a scale of least popular to most popular where white represents least and purple represents most. To add on, of the four artists, Rihanna is the least popular and Taylor Swift is the most popular. I also noticed that Taylor Swift gains most of her popularity from the west coast and northern states, while Rihanna gains most of her popularity from the south. Lastly, Luke Bryan is most popular among the states in the middle while Drake is most popular among states like California, New Mexico, and Texas.

name: Amber Guardado
comment info: I notice that some parts on the map of the United States is a darker shade of Purple, while others are lighter in certain areas. What might be going on in these graphs is for each artist being seen on Youtube, they get more popular, but in each state the amount of viewer is different depending on what is actually trending in that area.

comment info: The graphs might be relating the popularity of different top artists around the United States in relation to their amount of Youtube views. It can also be showing that Youtube is becoming less used to stream popular music now that apps such as Spotify and Pandora are available.

name: Claudia Benitez
comment info: The colored areas of the graphs represent popularity, dark purple being most popular and white being least popular. Taylor Swift seems to be the artist with the most dark purple areas while Rihanna seems to have the least amount of dark colored areas. This implies that Taylor Swift attracts a more diverse fan base than the other artists, because her graph seems to cover more demographics across the United States.

name: NyJay Poston
comment info: I wonder if this popularity is good or bad. name: Brianna Huertas
comment info: There are so many different aspects of these graphs. I noticed Luke Bryan is more popular in the northern states. I expected him to be way more popular in southern states because he is a country singer. I also expected Rihanna to be more popular in California. Looking at these graphs, I realize that there are a lot of stereotypes about which states typically listen to which type of music. For example, most people, including me, would think that the far eastern states would listen to Drake, but surprisingly, he is very popular in south western states. Another stereotype would be southerners listening to Taylor Swift a lot, yet she is not as popular as many may think she is there. These graphs have surprised me, and have caught me off guard because of these broken stereotypes.

replies.name: T
replies.comment info: I agree with what you're saying and would like to add on that I never saw it from that point of view. It is very strange why most southerners would not listen to country artists like Taylor Swift and Luke Bryan, yet in a way, it makes a lot of sense considering most of the southern states listen to Rihanna where there is a higher percentage of African-Americans. Stereotypes are all around we should not expect certain people in certain ares to listen to a specific type of music.

name: Andrew Burkhardt
comment info: Artists who tend to make the same genres of music tend to be popular in the same areas across the United States. Rihanna and Drake are know for their Pop/Hip-Hop songs, so they both seem to be popular in the Southern portion of the US. Their popularity moves up the East coast, going all the way up to the New York area. Taylor Swift and Luke Bryan, known for their country music, tend to be more popular in the Mid-West and places like Kentucky and Tennessee. Another thing that could cause this is the races most prevalent in each area. In the area where Rihanna and Drake are poupular artist, there is a more diverse population. In the areas where Taylor Swift and Luke Bryan are popular, there is a whiter population. The whiter the population, the more popular the country stars are.

name: Fabiola Polo
comment info: By looking at the graphs you can see how for each artist where they are most popular is usually in a clump, meaning those people being close they probably spread that music among themselves. Looking clisely you also see how Taylor Swift & Luke Bryant are most popular at the north/northeast, while Rhianna and Drake share the south just one is mostly in the east and the other in the west.

name: Bridgette
comment info:
I noticed:
- The numbers before each artist appear to be their ranking on the Billboard Top 100 artists, which were the most watched on YouTube.
- I notice that the heat map signifies how popular an artist is in a region. However, some regions may be more densely populated than others, so I wonder if that effects how it appears.
- Two of the artists, Rihanna and Drake, are POC and make hip-hop/rap/r&b music, and two of the artists, Taylor and Luke, are white and make country music.
- Rihanna appears to be more popular in the North East coast area and around Louisiana, Mississippi and Arkansas. Taylor Swift appears more popular in Montana, Idaho, Wyoming, Utah, Nevada and Colorado. She almost appears to have an inverse popularity of Rihanna’s. Where she is popular, Rihanna is not and vice versa.
- Drake appears more popular in Nevada, California, Southern Texas and North East coast area. Luke Bryan appears more popular in Ohio, Kentucky, West Virginia. Again, Luke Bryan appears to be popular inversely to where Drake is popular.
- Rihanna is popular in Democrat states in North East but also in some Republican states in the South. Taylor is popular mostly in Republican states, Drake is popular mostly in Democrat states and Luke is popular mostly in Republican states.

I wonder:
- What characteristics of an artist makes them popular in one region and not another? And do people listen to artists that they can relate to more?
- What impacts an artists popularity? Music genre? Race?

name: megan macias
comment info: I wonder why people aren't watching these artist in certain states or areas in the United States.  The graphs show how many people watch these artist on YouTube.

replies.name: Z
replies.comment info: The people who are not watching these 4 artists are watching other artists on youtube. The graph is based off the streams off of the youtube geocaode streaming data period and took the geocoe for these 4 artists.

name: chandler b
comment info: This graph is showing the popularity of the specific artist across the United States. I noticed that the trends for these artists are very different then what typical stereotypes would say. I also noticed that the rap/ hip pop is more popular on the coasts, while the country music is more popular in northern states. I wonder if the artist's managers have seen these statistics and if they have how will they increase the popularity in other states.

name: Moderator James
comment info:
Many of you wanted to compare thoughts about these four artists to what you noticed in the graphs. “I noticed -- in the graph and wonder why this is happening.”  Others tried to connect the regional popularity of an artist to what you know about the region. Combining perceptions of the artists with what you notice in the graphs and the region’s demographics could lead to interesting discussions about “What might be going on in this graph?” The moderators replied frequently about discerning the difference between a claim, which is supported by the graphs and factual information, and just an opinion. 

Thanks to all teachers and students who responded. Since we continue to post responses whenever they arrive, is there more that you notice?  More that you wonder? Talk to your classmates and read the moderators’ responses. Dig deeper into what the graphs show. Discuss what the graphs do not show. Perhaps you will find more things to notice, wonder, claim or conjecture. 

Please check back on Thursday, April 12 to see the Reveal with the original article, graphs for 46 other artists, information about the graphs, and the Stat Nuggets. And join us on the 2nd Tuesday of the month (May 8th) for the last "What's Going On In This Graph?" of the school year. Signing off -- Sharon in Boston, where a lot of Drake and Taylor Swift are streamed, and James Bush in Pittsburgh where no group stands out as more popular than another. Visit the archives to keep responding. Hope to see you in May.

comment info: I’ve noticed that the darker the shade, the more popular that artist is. I’ve noticed that Rihanna seems to be popular in the south. replies.comment info:
Welcome, Thomas.
Thank you for separating claim and opinion.  What you notice are facts from the graphs.  Your wonders may include opinions.  When, you say, "I believe", you're making clear that this is an opinion.  Interesting that Atlanta is not purple.  Does this change your opinion?

Hi, Thomas .....
Do you have any thoughts or opinions about what the map indicates for any of the other 3 artists?

name: Lipi
comment info: This graph shows the level of popularity for Billboard charting singers in all 50 states. It’s shows that Taylor Swift and Luke Bryan are well liked in almost all 50 states. However, Drake is popular is the Southwest, while Rihanna is more popular in the Southeast. I wonder what attracts these demographics to certain kinds of music. I notice that in all 50 states, people are interest in many different kinds of music.

replies.comment info: And, Lipi, I wonder why Drake is also popular in NYC, LA, DC, and Boston.  What do you think?

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to What’s Going On in This Graph?. Today’s graphs, in the form of maps, show the fandom across the country of four very popular musical singers. On Thursday, we’ll reveal many more.   

What do you NOTICE in these graphs? Share what you are noticing directly from the graphs.

What do you WONDER?  What are you curious about that comes from what you notice in the graphs?

What’s GOING ON in this graph?  What claims can you make based on what you notice?  Use evidence in the graphs to support your claims.  Take care to distinguish opinions from claims.

The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with “The story this graph might tell is ….”

Then, read some responses.  Click on "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going.  Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response. 

We look forward to reading your discoveries.

name: mari
comment info: i noticed that  the artists with more color are more popular then the  other ones

replies.comment info: Good morning, Mari.  Could you be more specific about what you mean by “more popular than the *other ones*”?   Which other ones?  Maybe read the release again and learn which artists are included.  Looking forward to hearing from you.

replies.comment info: So interesting Santiago that you noticed “the country music genre is more popular throughout the majority of the US.”  Please explain to our readers.   I really wonder why this could be true.  Do you – or any other readers, have a conjecture why this is so?

comment info: I noticed that there are different musical artists above the graphs of the US. I wonder why some musical artists are popular in a specific area. replies.comment info:
Good morning, Jakeila.
How did you come up with “the story this graph is telling is how people of color are more popular in southern areas and how white/Caucasian people are more popular in northern areas”?  Without backup from noticing what is in the graph, this is an opinion.  If you tell us what you notice in differences in the graphs, you can claim this distinction.  Claims can be more convincing than opinions.
Let us know what you find!

replies.comment info:
Max, thank you for separating claim from opinion.

You noticed that Taylor Swift is more popular than Drake.  What makes you say that?  She’s popular in the West, but where is Drake popular?  What does it mean to be “more popular”?

replies.comment info:
Jordan – Hope you see this reply since you responded 18 hours ago.  

You say that you “wonder why Taylor Swift is the most popular.”  Think about what “popular” means in these graphs?  Is it for the entire US or for regions?  And, how do these regions differ?  Does geographic area and/or population size figure in here?  Now, think again about your wonder “why Taylor Swift is the most popular”.
Let us know what you notice and wonder.

replies.comment info:
Maddie, you responded 20 hours ago, so I hope you will see this reply.

I bet others wondered “why Taylor Swift is more popular than Rihanna.”  What in the graphs do you base this on?   How do you reconcile this wonder with Rihanna being #2 in the Top 100 and Taylor Swift being only #18?  What’s going on here?
